content: End-to-end neural models have advanced question answering, but they struggle with answers and evidence spread across multiple documents. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) addresses this by combining information from multiple documents. Using hierarchies of coattention and self-attention, the CFC achieves a new state-of-the-art result of 70.6% on the Qangaroo WikiHop task, outperforming previous models by 3% accuracy. This model demonstrates the ability to reason over multiple documents for practical question answering systems. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) achieves a new state-of-the-art result of 70.6% on the blind test set, surpassing the previous best by 3% accuracy without using pretrained contextual encoders. This model focuses on multi-evidence question answering by aggregating information from multiple documents, inspired by coarse-grain and fine-grain reasoning. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) achieves a new state-of-the-art result of 70.6% accuracy on the blind Qangaroo WikiHop test set, surpassing the previous best by 3% without using pretrained contextual encoders. The CFC model combines coarse-grain reasoning, fine-grain reasoning, and hierarchical attention to select candidate answers based on support documents and a query. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) achieves a new state-of-the-art result on the blind Qangaroo WikiHop test set with 70.6% accuracy, surpassing the previous best by 3%. The CFC combines hierarchical attention to select candidate answers based on support documents and a query, improving exact match accuracy and F1 scores. The attention hierarchies of the coarse and fine-grain modules focus on distinct parts of the input, enabling the CFC to effectively represent a large collection of long documents. Common errors produced by CFC include difficulty in aggregating references, noise in distant supervision, and challenging relation types. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) achieves a new state-of-the-art result on the blind Qangaroo WikiHop test set with 70.6% accuracy by combining hierarchical attention to select candidate answers based on support documents and a query. The coarse-grain module summarizes support documents using coattention and self-attention, while the fine-grain module retrieves specific contexts for each candidate by identifying coreferent mentions and using coattention. This division of labor allows the attention hierarchies in each module to focus on different parts of the input, enabling the model to effectively represent a large number of potentially long support documents. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) achieves a new state-of-the-art result on the blind Qangaroo WikiHop test set with 70.6% accuracy by combining hierarchical attention to select candidate answers based on support documents and a query. The model uses bidirectional GRUs to encode sequences and a query projection layer for coattention between support documents and the query. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) utilizes bidirectional GRUs to encode support documents and queries, employing coattention and self-attention mechanisms to compare with candidate answers. Affinity matrices are computed between documents and queries, with summary vectors generated for support and query contexts. The coattention context is formed by concatenating document context and summary vectors. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) utilizes bidirectional GRUs to encode support documents and queries. It employs coattention and self-attention mechanisms to compare with candidate answers. The coattention context is formed by concatenating document context and summary vectors, followed by hierarchical self-attention to create a fixed-length summary vector. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) utilizes bidirectional GRUs to encode support documents and queries. It employs coattention and self-attention mechanisms to compare with candidate answers. The coattention context is used to compute a weighted sum over the context, followed by self-attention layers to produce summaries. The fixed-length summary vector of support documents is multiplied with the candidate answer summary to generate a coarse-grain score. The fine-grain module further refines the scoring process. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) utilizes bidirectional GRUs to encode support documents and queries. It employs coattention and self-attention mechanisms to compare with candidate answers. The fine-grain module finds specific context in supporting documents using coreference resolution and computes coattention between mention representations and the query to produce a fine-grain summary for scoring candidates. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) uses bidirectional GRUs to encode support documents and queries. It employs self-attention to represent mentions of the candidate and a linear layer to determine the candidate's score. The final score is a combination of coarse-grain and fine-grain scores, calculated using cross-entropy loss during training. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) combines coarse-grain and fine-grain scores to calculate the candidate's final score. The model is trained using cross-entropy loss and evaluated on multi-evidence question answering tasks. It achieves state-of-the-art results on the WikiHop dataset and significant performance improvement on the TriviaQA task. The WikiHop dataset facilitates the study of multi-evidence question answering by linking entities in a document corpus with a knowledge base. The Qangaroo WikiHop task involves selecting the correct candidate answer from a set of plausible options based on support documents, using a bipartite graph of documents and entities linked by knowledge base facts. The BiDAF Baseline achieves 54.5% accuracy on selecting correct candidate answers from support documents in the WikiHop task. The CFC model outperforms other models on the WikiHop leaderboard, achieving a new best accuracy of 70.6% on the blind, held-out test set. The CFC model achieves state-of-the-art results on both masked and unmasked versions of WikiHop, surpassing the previous best accuracy by 3% without using pretrained contextual encoders. The division of labor between coarse-grain and fine-grain modules allows for effective attention hierarchies, enabling better modeling of long documents. Additionally, the model performs well on TriviaQA, showcasing its effectiveness in aggregating evidence from multiple sentences. The study evaluates the model's effectiveness on TriviaQA by decomposing tasks into proposing candidate answers and reranking them. BiDAF++ is used for span extraction, and CFC for reranking. Reranking with CFC consistently improves performance. The study evaluates the effectiveness of a question answering model on TriviaQA by using BiDAF++ for span extraction and CFC for reranking. Reranking with CFC consistently improves performance, regardless of the candidate answer set obtained from the span extraction model. The CFC can be used to refine outputs produced by question answering models, with a gain of 3.1% EM and 3.0% F1 on the TriviaQA dev set. The coarse-grain and fine-grain modules significantly contribute to model performance, while replacing self-attention layers with mean-pooling and bidirectional GRUs with unidirectional GRUs result in less performance degradation. Replacing self-attention layers with mean-pooling and bidirectional GRUs with unidirectional GRUs results in less performance degradation. Replacing the encoder with a projection over word embeddings leads to a significant performance drop, highlighting the importance of contextual encodings capturing positional information. The fine-grain module consistently under-performs the coarse-grain module due to coreference resolution difficulties, but excels in examples with multiple support documents or lengthy support. The difficulty of coreference resolution in support documents leads to high precision and low recall in entity matching. The fine-grain model performs better with multiple or lengthy support documents due to its precise intra-document and inter-document dependency capture. Coattention layers focus on similar phrases between documents and queries, while self-attention layers capture entity characteristics. Fine-grain coattention and self-attention scores are not included in the main text but can be found in the Appendix. The document discusses fine-grain coattention and self-attention scores for queries related to administrative territorial entities and country of origin. Coattention aligns the relation part of the query to the context in the text, while self-attention focuses on relevant documents. Support documents provide information on literary works, authors, and related topics. The summary selfattention focuses on relevant documents for the query, while fine-grain coattention aligns the relation part of the query to the text context. Errors in the CFC model on the WikiHop development set are categorized into four types, with examples provided in the Appendix. The CFC model errors on the WikiHop development set are categorized into four types. The first type (42% of errors) results from aggregating the wrong reference. The second type (28% of errors) is due to unanswerable questions. The third type (22% of errors) occurs when queries have multiple correct answers. The CFC model errors on the WikiHop development set are categorized into four types: wrong reference aggregation (42% of errors), unanswerable questions (28% of errors), multiple correct answers for queries (22% of errors), and errors due to complex relation types like parent taxon (8% of errors). To address these errors, embedding relations using tunable symbolic embeddings along with fixed word embeddings can be considered. To reduce errors in question answering tasks, embedding relations using tunable symbolic embeddings and fixed word embeddings can be utilized. QA tasks involve various sources like Wikipedia, news articles, books, and trivia. While most QA tasks focus on single-document reasoning, the Qangaroo WikiHop dataset encourages reasoning across multiple documents. Query-focused multi-document summarization also requires aggregating information from multiple sources. Large-scale QA datasets have led to the development of end-to-end QA models with document attention mechanisms. Recent developments in question answering models have led to the creation of end-to-end QA models with various attention mechanisms, including cross-sequence attention models and reinforcement learning techniques. These models aim to improve the exploration of close answers and refine span-extraction output using convolutions, self-attention, and reranking models. The use of reinforcement learning, convolutions, self-attention, and reranking models in question answering models aims to improve exploration of close answers and refine span-extraction output. Attention mechanisms like coattention and self-attention have been successfully applied in various tasks such as machine translation, relation extraction, summarization, and textual entailment. In the CFC, a novel approach combines self-attention and coattention hierarchically to create effective conditional representations of long documents. Hierarchical coarse-to-fine modeling, gradually increasing complexity, is effective for modeling lengthy documents, as demonstrated in parsing, speech recognition, and machine translation. Neural coarse-to-fine modeling has also been applied to question answering. Modeling, such as the CFC approach, is effective for representing long documents. The CFC model, inspired by coarse-grain and fine-grain reasoning, outperforms previous methods in multi-evidence question answering tasks. It achieves 70.6% test accuracy on the WikiHop task. The complementary coarse-grain and fine-grain modules focus on different aspects of the input, making them effective for large document collections. In this work, the CFC achieves 70.6% test accuracy, surpassing previous methods by 3%. The model utilizes simple lexical matching for coreference resolution and is trained using Adam for 50 epochs. The integration of full-scale coreference resolution systems is a potential future direction. The model uses a batch size of 80 examples and an initial learning rate of 10^-3 with cosine learning rate decay. It outperforms other annealing heuristics and uses fixed embeddings with GRUs of hidden size 100. Regularization is done with dropout at various layers in the model. The model utilizes dropout at different layers with varying rates, including word dropout. Attention maps are generated by the CFC on the WikiHop development split.
